newsitem.title: USA: BroadVision to roll out WebApps products.
newsitem.headline: BroadVision to roll out WebApps products.

text.p: BroadVision Inc is expected on Monday to introduce One-to-One WebApps, a software family aimed at companies developing Web merchandising, self- service and content publishing applications.
The Los Altos-based company will also announce the launch of Version 2 of its BroadVision One-to-One flagship application system, company executives said.
Pehong Chen, president and chief executive of the company, said Version 2 enables companies to conduct business in much the same way as they do in face-to-face situations.

This includes listening, learning and interacting with customers, he said, adding BroadVision's products enable this to be done more effectively at a fraction of the cost of more traditional marketing methods.

The company specializes in developing software that enables organizations to conduct one-to-one personalized business on the Internet's World Wide Web, focussing on top 1,000 companies around the globe.
Robert Runge, vice president of marketing, said BroadVision, which completed its initial stock offering in June, has grown to 165 staff with 34 customers worldwide.
The software addresses issues of profiling, content management, matching and transactions, he added.
The Version 2 of One-to-One benefits from cumulative engineering effort of more than 100 man-years, and has been beta-tested by eight customers in five countries, he added.

The software -- which uses rules-based matching to generate content dynamically -- puts non-technical business management in direct control of specific "command posts" on a company's internal network, or intranet, or on the Internet.
One-to-One WebApps expands on the BroadVision platform to provide turnkey solutions for merchandising, content publishing and self-service.

Michael Kennedy, senior director of product marketing, said they have been developed in conjunction with leading companies, such as catalog marketing firm Fingerhut Companies for merchandising; NetRadio, Marketing 1:1 and Silicon Graphics Inc for content publishing and Advanta Corp for self-service applications.

Pricing for One-to-One WebApps starts at $30,000, in addition to the base price for BroadVision One-to-one V2, which starts at $60,000. The first version of One-to-One began delivery in December 1995.
